IRD_def: Researchers of different religions meet once a month for comparative scripture reading. The aim is to read texts of different religious traditions related to a specific topic each time. Members of the Institute will select the topics of the workshop in turn, and other members will choose the texts from each religious tradition under the specified topic and arrange them together as reading materials. The process of comparative scripture reading will include exegesis, comparison and dialogue.
aim: The Institute aims to conduct comparative research in the classical or scriptural traditions of the great world religions and to engage in inter-religious dialogue, promoting“a better quality of disagreement between religions”.
history: Institute of Comparative Scripture and Inter-religious Dialogue was founded in 2011.

IRD_activities.activity: There is a school for dialogue in the Focolare town at Tagaytay

structure: General Council, consisting of woman President, general counsellors, persons in charge of sections and central activities and representatives of the Movement in the various countries. Sections: (i) Focolarini - individual lay people living in small communities of men or women, known as 'Focolare', joined by married people living in their own homes but part of the communities, known as 'Married Focolarini'; the Focolare are the basic structure of the Movement. (ii) 'Volunteers' - men and women living in their own homes but totally sharing the spirituality of the Focolare and committed to live this spirituality in the various environments in which they work in order to bring about a renewal of society. (iii) 'Priests' - who have taken the Focolare spirituality as their own and with it animate their pastoral and ecclesial life. (iv) Movement of Religious Men and Women - Movement of men or women belonging to different congregations, sharing the spirituality of Focolare. (v) 'Gen' - young people (boys and girls) who commit themselves in a total way to live the Focolare spirituality and work with the other sections to bring about unity in the world.
other_relations: No information
IRD_def: The Focolare Movement is committed to promoting dialogue between religions, because the religious pluralism of the world should not be a cause of division and war, but contribute to the building of brotherhood and world peace.

2012: Worldwide educators meet in Rome: How can we best educate children in human values and faith? How can we give them an experience of God's love? These were questions raised by 180 educators from all over the world who attended a week of study and reflection, Rome, Italy

2013: The human person in Sub-Saharan Africa: A 10th course on inculturation has taken place at Mariapolis Piero's Centre for Inculturation. The 287 participants included clergy, laity and young people from all the geographic region of the African continent, Nairobi, Kenya

2013: Chiara Lubich: A Charism Between History and Culture: More than 600 people, including professors and scholars, gather at La Spapienza University to remember the figure of the Focolare founder, tracing the development and actualisations of her spiritual doctrine, Rome, Italy

general_activities.activity_description: Since 1974, Rissho Kosei-kai has conducted 'Donate-a-Meal Movement' and the money contributed by its members through the campaign has been accumulated as the Rissho Kosei-kai Donate-a-Meal Fund for Peace and is utilized for its wide variety of activities for world peace.;

In 1978, Rissho Kosei-kai established the Niwano Peace Foundation as one of the commemorative undertakings for the 40th anniversary of the organization's founding. Rissho Kosei-kai hopes that the foundation will contribute to the attainment of world peace through the encouragement of people of religion everywhere to cooperate toward this goal, as well as through the enhancement of cultural and educational activities based on the religious spirit.; 4. Since 1980, the foundation has awarded the Niwano Peace Prize to honor remarkable religious leaders or groups that contribute to world peace through interreligious dialogue, protection of human rights, and conflict resolution. The foundation also provides financial assistance for religiously inspired research activities and projects concerning thought, culture, science, education, and related subjects.; 5. Carrying out own religious activities, (studying the Lotus Sutra and the Buddha's teachings )

IRD_def: Pioneering effective, multi-sector training programs and community-based projects that promote genuine dialogue, cooperative problem solving, reconciliation, and non-violent solutions in over 25 conflict-affected countries on 4 continents.
aim: Committed to the development and implementation of innovative, sustainable strategies for conflict transformation and community reconciliation in societies where ethnic, religious, sectarian, or political conflict threatens the possibility of a healthy, inclusive democracy and sustainable development.
publications: 'Peacebuilding in Divided Communities': Karuna Center's Approach to Peacebuilding
'A Trainer's Guide to Interfaith Peacebuilding in Sri Lanka' (2013)
'The Pivotal Role of Acknowledgement in Social Healing' (2009)
'Preparing for Peace: Interethnic Dialogue and Communal Healing in Sri Lanka'(2003)
'CONTACT: Training a New Generation of Peacebuilders' (2002)
'Shadows and Light: Encounters in the Holy Land' (2000)

general_activities.activity_description: The programs explore the interweaving of social, political, and economic factors that contribute to conflict, recognizing that conflict transformation requires both individual and systemic change. They engage participants in analyzing the root causes of conflict, identifying strategic opportunities for intervention, and building skills for conflict resolution and prevention by applying the approach fits with local culture and respects the needs of those deeply impacted by violence and trauma;

Central to the work of Karuna Center is the skillful use of facilitated, structured dialogues. During well-facilitated dialogues participants can come to a profound recognition of the essential humanity of the other, to a sense of mutuality and common purpose, and to a willingness to move forward together;

The longer term programs include a "training of trainers" and mentoring in the design and delivery of peacebuilding projects. Former participants of Karuna Center programs not only bring social healing to their communities, but also facilitate dialogues and teach peacebuilding skills throughout their countries. They are thereby helping to build a critical mass of people committed to promoting peace and justice and preventing future violence;
Advocating to build consensus around the idea that putting a price on carbon by faciliating the Summit and discussions through local dialogues.

IRD_def: Pax Christi International works with Religions for Peace on the role of religions in the promotion of a culture of peace and Dialogue between the different religions is the tool for a better understanding and peaceful co-existence.
finances: Sections' dues. Other sources: donations, subsidies.
aim: Based on the gospel and inspired by faith, the organisation aims to transform a world shaken by violence, terrorism, deepening inequalities and global insecurity; to create a culture of peace with religion as an unequivocal force for peace and social justice; to work towards non-violence, demilitarization and disarmament, human security, human rights and the rule of law as the basis of peaceful societies; to bring together people from various backgrounds and cultures.

general_activities.activity_description: Pax Christi facilitates and supports reconciliation and peace building processes which help communities to look at the past and develop a path towards lasting peace rooted in truth and justice (Just Peace). Pax Christi promotes peacekeeping skills of dialogue, mediation, and conflict resolution; 3.Education & Youth Work for Peace: Pax Christi contributes to a culture of peace by encouraging models of education that use, for example, youth exchanges, alternative peace service, voluntary peace work, and peace weeks; 4.Nonviolent Social Change: Pax Christi's dedication to peace is translated into the countless nonviolent actions of its members around the world. This includes, for instance, organizing conferences and debates, defending the rights of conscientious objectors, efforts to heal ethnic or religious divisions, solidarity delegations and missions to areas of conflict, and public witness for peace;

general_activities.activity_name: Interfaith and Intercultural Cooperation for Peace
general_activities.activity_description: Pax Christi creates opportunities for inter-faith dialogue and cooperation in order to promote peace and social justice with efforts towards Islam and Muslim communities;

By developing a spirituality and theology of peace to insert moral and ethical principles on issues of war and peace into the public and political arenas; 7.Advocacy and Campaigning: Through its representative status with international bodies such as the United Nations, UNESCO, the EU, and the Council of Europe, Pax Christi brings the experiences and concerns of its members in the Global Network to the international arena. On a national level, Pax Christi Member Organisations engage in advocacy appropriate to their own unique social and political context;

Pax Christi International increases the capacity and effectiveness of the Pax Christi movement and global network. Frequent continental and regional gatherings play a key role in facilitating consultation and exchanges among Pax Christi Member Organisations around the world;

history: 13 Mar 1945. Reorganized Dec 1950. Officially consecrated as Movement of the Church, 1952. Also referred to as Pax Christi International. Laureate of the UNESCO Peace Prize 1983. Statutes revised Apr 2006. Registered in accordance with Belgian law.

name_en: Forum for Development, Culture and Dialogue
structure: 7 members of the Board and 7 Staff
other_relations: No information
IRD_def: The Forum for Development, Culture and Dialogue respects the dignity of every human being, values the diversity of cultures in the Middle East, encourages dialogue and understanding as a means of resolving conflict, and perceives justice as the lasting basis of peace.
aim: Aiming to promote peacebuilding, equal citizenship, and human rights in the Middle East by creating common spaces for dialogue and building the capacity of community and civil society groups to be catalysts for peace, with a focus on women and youth.

general_activities.activity_name: Construction of Citizenship in the Arab World
general_activities.activity_description: The training aims to explore the compatibility between Arab culture and religions and Human Rights, and to construct an alternative Arab based understanding of citizenship and Human Rights;

The project proposal is aiming for a more just and equitable society through legal reform and the amendment of the sectarian personal status codes through working with religious leaders and building their capacities in their service provision and enhancing their legal literacy on matters that are affected by personal status laws;

The objective is to provide a new perspective of peacebuilding and conflict resolution skills and techniques to civil society leaders, in order to widen their horizons and their capabilities on how they can act for peace in their communities. This project aims to gather young civil society leaders coming from different institutions in Lebanon, such as scouts, religious based institutions for youth, youth committees and clubs;

general_activities.activity_name: Peacebuilding by Active Citizenship in Iraq
general_activities.activity_description: A 3-year project, gathering 18 representatives of Iraqi NGOs (aged 24-32) and 8 Iraqi University students from various areas in Iraq to promote advocacy and mobilization by empowering Iraqi students and workers in Iraqi NGOs to engage in active citizenship as well as to develop participants' skills in implementing projects and to advocate for peacebuilding;

general_activities.activity_name: Towards Peacebuilding in a Lebanese Context
general_activities.activity_description: A 3-year project, gathering students of theological and religious institutions in their final two years of study (new group of participants each year) to enhance bridges between future leaders of different confessional backgrounds and to increase linkages and communication among them as well as to deepen the understanding of students of various confessions in Lebanon for peacebuilding and to exchange their points of view on peacebuildling issues.

IRD_activities.activity: Alexandria Process: A three-day summit in Alexandria, Egypt in January 2002 between senior Christian, Jewish and Muslim leaders resulted in the First Alexandria Declaration of the Religious Leaders of the Holy Land, which condemned violence and pledged to work for peace. A Permanent Committee for the Implementation of the Alexandria Declaration (PCIAD) was established from the signatories and other spiritual leaders and has since met regularly;

Agreement between The Chief Rabbis of Israel and The Archbishop of Canterbury: They signed a joint Declaration in 2006 which sets out a framework for continuing dialogue between them, committing themselves to further meetings in Jerusalem and at Lambeth and to invite others in our wider communities to join with us;

Dialogues Building Bridges: Five pairs of scholars (each consisting of one Muslim and one Christian) presented a pair of papers. In the first four sessions each paper was followed by a prepared response from the scholar of the other faith to the presenter. After the fifth pair participants split into small groups to consider ways of carrying the dialogue forward. Subsequent meetings have focused on a particular theme. The activities were held annually from 2002-2007.

IRD_def: The Jordanian Interfaith Coexistence Research Center was established with the aim of using research, dialogue, and practical initiatives to promote values of peaceful interfaith coexistence.
aim: JICRC aims to develop and implement educational programs geared towards developing the concepts of peace building using the interfaith perspective of human dignity, equality, justice and freedom. These programs tackle issues of: Coexistence, Democracy, Women's Rights and empowerment in the MENA region, Children's Rights and Youth rights, and religious freedom.

general_activities.activity_description: The program consists of initiatives of workshops, camps and conferences, which provide an open forum for women to interact using the core interfaith values as a foundation for building harmony, religious coexistence, cultural understanding, gender equality, and peace. The ultimate goal of the programe is to transform women into agents of peace in their communities and in the world;

JICRC provides a venue for Muslim and Christian youth to dialogue and to build relationships of respect and understanding. Youth who have the passion and the capacity to promote peace and understanding between the faith traditions will become the most effective future spokespersons for the cause of peaceful coexistence. The program includes conferences, camps and workshops;
JICRC has hosted students for internships since 2004. The center has received interns from the US and Europe, for both short and long term positions.

IRD_def: The LWF strives to put our faith into action within and beyond the communion. This action takes a variety of forms from theological reflection and dialogue with other churches and faiths, to deepening relationships, sharing about our faith, serving those in need and advocating for a more just, peaceful and reconciled world.
events: 2003: The Tenth Assembly, Winnipeg, Canada
2010: The Eleventh Assembly, Stuttgart, Germany
aim: The LWF aims to build up a communion in Christ living and working together for a just, peaceful, and reconciled world.
history: The LWF was established in 1947 as a Federation of Lutheran churches. Lutherans worldwide wanted to confess, reflect, reconcile, and to respond together to human suffering in the aftermath of the Second World War.
